Hilbert and Quot Functors

Assjock
Algebraic Geometry Algebraic Geometry

发布于：Jun 3, 2024

13.4k words

83 min

WARNING: 本文可能不适合人类阅读, 因为有着一堆跳步以及个人记号.

这篇文章来自于我对moduli space 的一些初步了解. 主要抄了 Birkar 的 Topics in Algebraic Geometry 以及Harvard 的MATH259 的notes.

何谓moduli space? Fine moduli space M\mathcal{M}M 即是对moduli functor FFF 的一个representative. 说人话就是对于任意 scheme TTT over base TTT, 我们有 F(T)≅M(T)F(T)\cong \mathcal{M}(T)F(T)≅M(T), 这里M(T)\mathcal{M}(T)M(T) 是 TTT-points of M\mathcal{M}M. 我们同时可以考虑M(M)\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{M})M(M) 中的idMid_{\mathcal{M}}idM​ 以及其所对应的F(M)F(\mathcal{M})F(M) 中的元素U\mathfrak{U}U, 这个U\mathfrak{U}U 叫做universal family. 取出这个U\mathfrak{U}U 有什么好处呢? 如果我们考虑F(T)F(T)F(T) 中的另一个元素V\mathfrak{V}V, 通过一个类似Yoneda lemma 的讨论, 可以证明V\mathfrak{V}V 是U\mathfrak{U}U 的一个通过M(T)\mathcal{M}(T)M(T) 中的某一个点的pullback, 即这些元素和fibre 能够做出一个对应.

本文中讨论的Hilbert scheme 以及 Quot scheme 就是最为简单的fine moduli space 的例子, 这部分工作被记录与Grothendieck 的FGA. 同样也可以想一想如果把global section functor 作为一个moduli functor, 那么它是否存在fine moduli space 呢? 如果存在, 这个space 是什么以及上面的universal family 又是什么呢?

Ans: AS1\mathbb{A}_{S}^{1}AS1​ and x∈OS[x]x\in \mathcal{O}_{S}[x]x∈OS​[x].

Hilbert and Quot functors

In this section, we will give definitions of Hilb\mathcal{H}ilbHilb and Quot\mathcal{Q}uotQuot functors, which are the basis of the most moduli functors. We will consider those noetherian schemes over some noetherian scheme YYY.

Definition 1. For XXX projective scheme over kkk, L\mathcal{L}L is an invertible sheaf on XXX, F\mathcal{F}F is coherent sheaf on XXX. Then the function Φ(l)=χ(X,F⊗L⊗l)\Phi(l)=\chi(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes l})Φ(l)=χ(X,F⊗L⊗l) is a polynomial in Q[t]\mathbb{Q}[t]Q[t]. We call this polynomial Hilbert polynomial respect to L\mathcal{L}L of F\mathcal{F}F. (If using OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​ as the coherent sheaf, we’ll call it the Hilbert polynomial of XXX.)

Let NSch/Y\mathrm{NSch}/YNSch/Y denote the category of noetherian schemes over YYY, we now give the definition of Hilbert functor.

Definition 2. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes, L\mathcal{L}L be an invertible sheaf on XXX. Let Φ∈Q[t]\Phi\in \mathbb{Q}[t]Φ∈Q[t] be a polynomial. Define the Hilbert functor HilbX/YΦ,L:(NSch/Y)op→Set\mathcal{H}ilb_{X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}: (\mathrm{NSch} /Y)^{op}\to \mathrm{Set}HilbX/YΦ,L​:(NSch/Y)op→Set by HilbX/YΦ,L(S)={closed subschemes Z of XS(=X×YS) flat over S s.t. for each s∈S,Φs=Φ}{H}ilb_{X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)=\{\text{closed subschemes } Z \text{ of }X_{S}(=X\times_{Y}S) \text{ flat over } S \text{ s.t. for each }s\in S, \Phi_{s}=\Phi\}HilbX/YΦ,L​(S)={closed subschemes Z of XS​(=X×Y​S) flat over S s.t. for each s∈S,Φs​=Φ}. Here Φs\Phi_{s}Φs​ it the Hilbert polynomial of fibre ZsZ_{s}Zs​ with respect to Ls\mathcal{L}_{s}Ls​(pullback of L\mathcal{L}L along Zs→{s}→SZ_{s}\to \{s\}\to SZs​→{s}→S).

To make this definition more concrete, we need a lemma:

Lemma 1. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. If F\mathcal{F}F is flat over YYY, then the Hilbert polynomial Φy\Phi_{y}Φy​ of Fy\mathcal{F}_{y}Fy​ on XyX_{y}Xy​ viewed as a function in yyy is locally constant on YYY. If YYY is integral, then the converse also holds.

Proof

Proof. Ha3 III theorem 9.9. ◻

This lemma implies the functor HilbX/YΦ,L{H}ilb_{X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}HilbX/YΦ,L​ is well-defined since the fibre has the same Hilbert polynomial. We also give a generalization of Hilbert functor:

Definition 3. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes and L\mathcal{L}L an invertible sheaf on XXX, F\mathcal{F}F coherent sheaf on XXX. Let Φ∈Q[t]\Phi\in \mathbb{Q}[t]Φ∈Q[t] be a polynomial. Then the Quot functor QuotF/X/YΦ,L:(NSch/Y)op→Set\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}:(\mathrm{NSch}/Y)^{op}\to \mathrm{Set}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​:(NSch/Y)op→Set by QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)={coherent quotients G of FS(pullback of F to XS) flat over S with Φs=Φ}\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)=\{\text{coherent quotients } \mathcal{G} \text{ of } \mathcal{F}_{S} (\text{pullback of }\mathcal{F} \text{ to }X_{S}) \text{ flat over } S \text{ with } \Phi_{s} = \Phi\}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S)={coherent quotients G of FS​(pullback of F to XS​) flat over S with Φs​=Φ}. Here Φs\Phi_{s}Φs​ is the Hilbert polynomial of the sheaf Gs\mathcal{G}_{s}Gs​ on the fibre XsX_{s}Xs​ of XS→SX_{S}\to SXS​→S over s∈Ss\in Ss∈S with respect to L\mathcal{L}L.

The Hilbert functor is the special case of Quot functor when F=OX\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{O}_{X}F=OX​(consider the coherent ideal sheaves and their quotients). Now for any morphism v:T→Sv:T\to Sv:T→S over YYY, the functor structure of QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is given by pulling back elements in QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S) via vvv. To check the Hilbert polynomial is the same, we can use the following lemma:

Lemma 2. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes, L\mathcal{L}L an invertible sheaf on XXX, F\mathcal{F}F a coherent sheaf on XXX and F→G\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{G}F→G a coherent quotient such that G\mathcal{G}G is flat over YYY with Hilbert polynomial Φ\PhiΦ with respect to L\mathcal{L}L . Let g:S→Yg:S\to Yg:S→Y be a morphism from a noetherian scheme. Then FS→GS\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{G}_{S}FS​→GS​ is a coherent quotient with GS\mathcal{G}_{S}GS​ flat over SSS with the Hilbert polynomial Φ\PhiΦ.

Proof

Proof. Only need to show the assertion for Hilbert polynomial. Let g(s)=yg(s)=yg(s)=y be some point in YYY and the corresponding fibres be XS,sX_{S,s}XS,s​ and XyX_{y}Xy​. The bottom arrow pullback square

is from the field extension k(y)→k(s)k(y)\to k(s)k(y)→k(s) and thus a flat morphism. By the flat base change, Hi(Xy,Fy)⊗k(s)=Hi(XS,s,Fs)H^{i}(X_{y},\mathcal{F}_{y})\otimes k(s)=H^{i}(X_{S,s},\mathcal{F}_{s})Hi(Xy​,Fy​)⊗k(s)=Hi(XS,s​,Fs​), so dim⁡k(y)Hi(Xy,Fy)=dim⁡k(s)Hi(XS,s,Fs)\dim_{k(y)}H^{i}(X_{y},\mathcal{F}_{y})=\dim_{k(s)}H^{i}(X_{S,s},\mathcal{F}_{s})dimk(y)​Hi(Xy​,Fy​)=dimk(s)​Hi(XS,s​,Fs​). So χ(Xy,Fy)=χ(XS,s,Fs)\chi(X_{y},\mathcal{F}_{y})=\chi(X_{S,s},\mathcal{F}_{s})χ(Xy​,Fy​)=χ(XS,s​,Fs​) and the Hilbert polynomial is the same by the same arguments. ◻

Definition 4. We say the functor QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is representable if we have the following:

  • a scheme QuotF/X/YΦ,LQuot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ in NSch/Y\mathrm{NSch} /YNSch/Y called the Quot scheme.

  • a coherent sheaf G∈QuotF/X/YΦ,L(QuotF/X/YΦ,L)\mathfrak{G}\in \mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(Quot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}})G∈QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(QuotF/X/YΦ,L​) on X×YQuotF/X/YΦ,LX\times_{Y}Quot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}X×Y​QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ called the universal family.

  • the fundamental isomorphism HomSch/Y(S,QuotF/X/YΦ,L)→≃QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Sch}/Y}(S,Quot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}})\xrightarrow{\simeq}\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)HomSch/Y​(S,QuotF/X/YΦ,L​)≃​QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S) which sends a morphism S→QuotF/X/YΦ,LS\to Quot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}S→QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ to the pullback of G\mathfrak{G}G via the induced morphism XS→X×YQuotF/X/YΦ,LX_{S}\to X\times_{Y} Quot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}XS​→X×Y​QuotF/X/YΦ,L​.

When F=OX\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{O}_{X}F=OX​, we denote the QuotF/X/YΦ,LQuot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ by HilbX/YΦ,LHilb_{X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}HilbX/YΦ,L​ and call it the Hilbert scheme of XXX over YYY respect to L\mathcal{L}L.

Example 1. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes, L=OX(1)\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)L=OX​(1), Φ=1\Phi=1Φ=1. Then the closed subschemes of fibre of fff with Hilbert polynomial Φ\PhiΦ are those closed points(Just note that deg⁡Φ=dim⁡SuppOXy\deg \Phi=\dim \mathrm{Supp}\mathcal{O}_{X_{y}}degΦ=dimSuppOXy​​). We guess: HilbX/YΦ,L=XHilb_{X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}=XHilbX/YΦ,L​=X and the universal family is the sheaf associated to the diagonal subscheme Δ\DeltaΔ of X×YXX\times_{Y} XX×Y​X. Now we check it. If S∈NSch/YS\in \mathrm{NSch}/ YS∈NSch/Y and Z⊂XSZ\subset X_{S}Z⊂XS​ a closed subscheme flat over SSS with fibres having Hilbert polynomial Φ\PhiΦ, then Z→SZ\to SZ→S is an isomorphism(consider those fibres). So we have the morphism S→XS\to XS→X and S→ΔS\to \DeltaS→Δ as desired.

The Grassmannian

We start with an example

Example 2. Let kkk be an algebraically closed field, VVV an nnn-dimensional vector space, d≥0d\geq 0d≥0. The Grassmannian Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d) is the space which parametrized the (n−d)(n-d)(n−d)-dimensional subspace of VVV. Let WWW be a ddd-dimensional kkk vector space. Then any subspace V′V'V′ of VVV of dimension n−dn-dn−d is kernel of some ϕ:V→W\phi:V\to Wϕ:V→W, and the matrix represented MϕM_{\phi}Mϕ​ representing ϕ\phiϕ(up to an isomorphism of WWW). The set of all d×nd\times nd×n matrices over kkk is parametrized by the affine space Adn\mathbb{A}^{dn}Adn and the subset of rank ddd form an open set U⊂AdnU\subset \mathbb{A}^{dn}U⊂Adn. So Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d) is the quotient of UUU by GL(k,d)GL(k,d)GL(k,d).

The Grassmannian can be described as follows: For any point in Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d), which is represented by a matrix MMM, with entries mijm_{ij}mij​ and columns γ1,…,γn\gamma_{1},\dots, \gamma_{n}γ1​,…,γn​. Let MIM_{I}MI​ be the d×dd\times dd×d submatrix of MMM with index set I⊂{1,…,n}I\subset \{1,\dots, n\}I⊂{1,…,n}. After choosing appropriate representitives, we may assume MIM_{I}MI​ is the identity matrix, and then the other entries not in MIM_{I}MI​ are uniquely determined. So all points MMM of Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d) with MI≠0M_{I}\neq 0MI​=0 simply correspond to the points of Adn−d2\mathbb{A}^{dn-d^{2}}Adn−d2. Let GIG_{I}GI​ be the set of such points. For I,JI, JI,J two index sets of columns, we let GI,JG_{I,J}GI,J​ be the set of those points M∈GIM\in G_{I}M∈GI​ with det⁡MJ≠0\det M_{J}\neq 0detMJ​=0. Define a morphism fI,J:GI,J→GJ,If_{I,J}:G_{I,J}\to G_{J,I}fI,J​:GI,J​→GJ,I​ by mapping MMM to MJ−1MM_{J}^{-1}MMJ−1​M. If I,J,KI,J,KI,J,K are three index sets of columns, then fI,J=fJ,K∘fI,Jf_{I,J}=f_{J,K}\circ f_{I,J}fI,J​=fJ,K​∘fI,J​. fI,I=idf_{I,I}=idfI,I​=id so fI,Jf_{I,J}fI,J​ are all isomorphisms. We can give Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d)Grass(V,d) a scheme structure by gluing GIG_{I}GI​ via fI,Jf_{I,J}fI,J​.

We will need the existence of Grassmannian.

Theorem 1. Let YYY be noetherian scheme and E\mathcal{E}E a locally free sheaf of rank nnn. Then there exists a unique (up to isomorphism) scheme Grass(E,d)Grass(\mathcal{E},d)Grass(E,d) with a closed immersion into P(∧dE)\mathbb{P}(\wedge^{d}\mathcal{E})P(∧dE) and the induced morphism π:Grass(E,d)→Y\pi: Grass(\mathcal{E},d)\to Yπ:Grass(E,d)→Y and a rank ddd locally free quotient sheaf π∗E→G\pi^{*}\mathcal{E}\to \mathfrak{G}π∗E→G satisfying: for any morhism g:S→Yg:S\to Yg:S→Y and any rank ddd locally free quotient g∗E→Gg^{*}\mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{G}g∗E→G, there’s a unique morphism h:S→Grass(E,d)h:S\to Grass(\mathcal{E},d)h:S→Grass(E,d) over YYY s.t. g∗E→Gg^{*}\mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{G}g∗E→G.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. See G&W2 theorem 8.17. ◻

Corollary 1. Let X=YX=YX=Y be noetherian scheme and f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y the identity morphism,L=OX\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}_{X}L=OX​, F\mathcal{F}F locally free sheaf of rank nnn, Φ=d\Phi=dΦ=d. Then QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is represented by Grass(F,d)Grass(\mathcal{F},d)Grass(F,d).

Proof

Proof. Let g:S→Yg:S\to Yg:S→Y be a morphism from a noetherian scheme. The fibre Xs=Speck(s)X_{s}=\mathrm{Spec} k(s)Xs​=Speck(s), and Fs\mathcal{F}_{s}Fs​ is an nnn-dimensional vector space. For G∈QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{G}\in \mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)G∈QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S), consider Gs\mathcal{G}_{s}Gs​ on the fibre XsX_{s}Xs​, Φs=d\Phi_{s}=dΦs​=d so Gs\mathcal{G}_{s}Gs​ is a ddd-dimensional quotient of Fs\mathcal{F}_{s}Fs​. G\mathcal{G}G is flat so it’s locally free of rank ddd. By above theorem, the surjection FS→G\mathcal{F}_{S}\to\mathcal{G}FS​→G uniquely determines a morphism h:S→Grass(F,d)h:S\to Grass(\mathcal{F},d)h:S→Grass(F,d) and π∗F→G\pi^{*}\mathcal{F}\to \mathfrak{G}π∗F→G pulls back to g∗F→Gg^{*}\mathcal{F}\to \mathcal{G}g∗F→G. ◻

Castelnuovo-Mumford regularity

We start with a useful lemma:

Lemma 3. Let X=ProjA[t0,…,tn]X=\mathrm{Proj} A[t_{0},\dots,t_{n}]X=ProjA[t0​,…,tn​], h∈A[t0,…,tn]h\in A[t_{0},\dots, t_{n}]h∈A[t0​,…,tn​] a homogeneous polynomial, and HHH the closed subscheme defined by hhh, F\mathcal{F}F a coherent sheaf on XXX. If HHH does not contain any of the associated points of F\mathcal{F}F, then the sequence 0→F⊗O(−H)→F⊗OX→F⊗OH→00\to \mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}(-H)\to \mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{O}_{H}\to 00→F⊗O(−H)→F⊗OX​→F⊗OH​→0 is exact.

Proof

Proof. First the finiteness of associated points is by 05AF1. The problem is local so we reduce to the affine case. The sequence 0→OX(−H)→⋅hOX→OH→00\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(-H)\xrightarrow{\cdot h}\mathcal{O}_{X}\to \mathcal{O}_{H}\to 00→OX​(−H)⋅h​OX​→OH​→0 is exact. Since HHH does not contain any associated points of F\mathcal{F}F, hhh is not a zero divisor in H0(X,F)H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F})H0(X,F) (c.f. 00LD1). So F(−1)→⋅hF\mathcal{F}(-1)\xrightarrow{\cdot h}\mathcal{F}F(−1)⋅h​F is injective. We have the desired exact sequence 0→F(−1)→⋅hF→FH→00\to \mathcal{F}(-1)\xrightarrow{\cdot h}\mathcal{F}\to\mathcal{F}_{H}\to 00→F(−1)⋅h​F→FH​→0. ◻

Note that Tor1(OX,F)=0\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X},\mathcal{F})=0Tor1​(OX​,F)=0 since OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​ is flat, the exactness of the above sequence is equivalent to Tor1(OX,F)→Tor1(OH,F)\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X},\mathcal{F})\to \mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{H},\mathcal{F})Tor1​(OX​,F)→Tor1​(OH​,F) is surjective. So we have Tor1(OH,F)=0\mathrm{Tor}_{1}(\mathcal{O}_{H},\mathcal{F})=0Tor1​(OH​,F)=0.

Definition 5. Let XXX be a projective scheme over a field kkk, let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. The sheaf F\mathcal{F}F is said to be mmm-regular if Hp(X,F(m−p))=0H^{p}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-p))=0Hp(X,F(m−p))=0 for any p>0p>0p>0 (with the respect to a very ample sheaf OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1)).

We give two useful theorems. They will be used in the proof of the main theorem.

Theorem 2. Let XXX be a projective scheme over a field kkk. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX which is mmm-regular. Then we have the following properties:

  1. F\mathcal{F}F is lll-regular for any l≥ml\geq ml≥m.

  2. the natural map H0(X,OX(1))⊗H0(X,F(l))→H0(X,F(l+1))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(1))\otimes H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(l))\to H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(l+1))H0(X,OX​(1))⊗H0(X,F(l))→H0(X,F(l+1)) is surjective for any l≥ml\geq ml≥m.

  3. F(l)\mathcal{F}(l)F(l) is generated by global sections for any l≥ml\geq ml≥m.

Proof

Proof. We first reduce to the case X=PknX=\mathbb{P}_{k}^{n}X=Pkn​. Let i:X→Pkni:X\to \mathbb{P}_{k}^{n}i:X→Pkn​ be the closed immersion. Note that Hi(X,F(l))=Hi(Pkn,i∗F(l))H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(l))=H^{i}(\mathbb{P}_{k}^{n},i_{*}\mathcal{F}(l))Hi(X,F(l))=Hi(Pkn​,i∗​F(l)) for any iii. Also (i∗F)y={0if y≠i(x) for any xFxif y=i(x) for some x(i_{*}\mathcal{F})_{y}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &0& \text{if } y\neq i(x) \text{ for any }x\\ &\mathcal{F}_{x} &\text{if }y=i(x) \text{ for some }x \end{aligned}\right.(i∗​F)y​={​0Fx​​if y=i(x) for any xif y=i(x) for some x​. So i∗F(l)i_{*}\mathcal{F}(l)i∗​F(l) is generated by global sections if and only if F(l)\mathcal{F}(l)F(l) is generated by global sections.

Now we assume X=PknX=\mathbb{P}_{k}^{n}X=Pkn​. Using the cohomology base change we may assume kkk is infinite field. We use the induction on nnn. The associated points of F\mathcal{F}F forms a finite subset, so there’s a hyperplane HHH which does not contain any associated point of F\mathcal{F}F. Consider the exact sequence 0→F(m−i−1)→F(m−i)→OH→00\to \mathcal{F}(m-i-1)\to \mathcal{F}(m-i)\to \mathcal{O}_{H}\to 00→F(m−i−1)→F(m−i)→OH​→0. Taking long exact sequence we get

⋯→Hi(X,F(m−i))→Hi(X,FH(m−i))→Hi+1(X,F(m−i−1))→⋯\cdots\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-i))\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}_{H}(m-i))\to H^{i+1}(X,\mathcal{F}(m-i-1))\to \cdots⋯→Hi(X,F(m−i))→Hi(X,FH​(m−i))→Hi+1(X,F(m−i−1))→⋯

so FH\mathcal{F}_{H}FH​ is also mmm-regular. Since H≅Pkn−1H\cong \mathbb{P}_{k}^{n-1}H≅Pkn−1​, by inductive hypothesis, the assertions also holds for FH\mathcal{F}_{H}FH​.

For 1, we can use induction on lll. From the exact sequence Hi(X,F(l−1))→Hi(X,F(l))→Hi(X,FH(l))H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(l-1))\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(l))\to H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}_{H}(l))Hi(X,F(l−1))→Hi(X,F(l))→Hi(X,FH​(l)), the first and the last term vanishes by the inductive hypothesis. So Hi(X,F(l))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}(l))=0Hi(X,F(l))=0 and thus F\mathcal{F}F is lll-regular.

For 2, consider the commutative diagram

The top morphism is the tensor product of two surjective morphism so it’s surjective. By inductive hypothesis, τ\tauτ is also surjective, so ν∘μ\nu\circ \muν∘μ is surjective and H0(X,F(l+1))=imμ+kerνH^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(l+1))=\mathrm{im} \mu+\mathrm{ker}\nuH0(X,F(l+1))=imμ+kerν. The bottom row is exact, we also have H0(X,F(l+1))=imμ+imαH^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(l+1))=\mathrm{im}\mu+\mathrm{im} \alphaH0(X,F(l+1))=imμ+imα. Stratification of Hilbert polynomial

We state a commutative algebra lemma and its corollary first.

Lemma 4. Let AAA be a noetherian domain, BBB a finite type AAA-algebra. Let MMM be a finite type BBB-module and. Then there exists f∈Af\in Af∈A, f≠0f\neq 0f=0 such that MfM_{f}Mf​ if free over AAA.

Corollary 2 (generic flatness). Let SSS be a noetherian integral scheme. Let p:X→Sp:X\to Sp:X→S be a finite type morphism and let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. Then there exists a nonempty open subscheme U⊂SU\subset SU⊂S such that the restriction of F\mathcal{F}F to XU=p−1(U)X_{U}=p^{-1}(U)XU​=p−1(U) is flat over OU\mathcal{O}_{U}OU​.

Theorem 4 (base change without flatness). Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism, u:Y′→Yu:Y'\to Yu:Y′→Y a morphism between noetherian schemes. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. Then the base change morphism u∗f∗F(d)→f∗′u′∗F(d)u^{*}f_{*}\mathcal{F}(d)\to f'_{*}u'^{*}\mathcal{F}(d)u∗f∗​F(d)→f∗′​u′∗F(d) is an isomorphism for d≫0d\gg 0d≫0.

Proof

Proof. The problem is local on YYY so we may assume Y=SpecAY=\mathrm{Spec}AY=SpecA. We also reduce to the case Y′=SpecA′Y'=\mathrm{Spec} A'Y′=SpecA′ and X=PAnX=\mathbb{P}_{A}^{n}X=PAn​ using flat base change. Take a resolution ⨁iOX(ai)→⨁jOX(bj)→F→0\bigoplus\limits_{i}\mathcal{O}_{X}(a_{i})\to \bigoplus\limits_{j}\mathcal{O}_{X}(b_{j})\to \mathcal{F}\to 0i⨁​OX​(ai​)→j⨁​OX​(bj​)→F→0 and pull back this exact sequence via u′u'u′, we get ⨁iOX′(ai)→⨁jOX′(bj)→u∗F→0\bigoplus\limits_{i}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(a_{i})\to \bigoplus\limits_{j}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(b_{j})\to u^{*}\mathcal{F}\to 0i⨁​OX′​(ai​)→j⨁​OX′​(bj​)→u∗F→0. After twisting by OX(d)\mathcal{O}_{X}(d)OX​(d) (resp. OX′(d)\mathcal{O}_{X'}(d)OX′​(d)) for d≫0d\gg 0d≫0, those higher cohomology vanish so apply H0H^{0}H0 gives a resolution of H0(X,F(d))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(d))H0(X,F(d)) as AAA-module and H0(X′,u′∗F(d))H^{0}(X',u'^{*}\mathcal{F}(d))H0(X′,u′∗F(d)) as A′A'A′-module. Note the sections of OX(a)\mathcal{O}_{X}(a)OX​(a) are just the degree aaa polynomials over AAA, we have H0(X,OX(a))⊗AA′≅H0(X′,OX′(a))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(a))\otimes_{A} A'\cong H^{0}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(a))H0(X,OX​(a))⊗A​A′≅H0(X′,OX′​(a)). Tensoring A′A'A′ with the resolution of H0(X,F(d))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(d))H0(X,F(d)) we get a resolution of H0(X,F(d))⊗AA′H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(d))\otimes_{A} A'H0(X,F(d))⊗A​A′, which is also a resolution of H0(X′,u′∗F(d))H^{0}(X',u'^{*}\mathcal{F}(d))H0(X′,u′∗F(d)). Since the base change morphism commutes with those for F(d)\mathcal{F}(d)F(d), we conclude that the base change morphism of F(d)\mathcal{F}(d)F(d) is an isomorphism. ◻

Theorem 5. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism of noetherian schemes and F\mathcal{F}F a coherent sheaf on XXX. Then fff is flat over YYY if and only if f∗F(d)f_{*}\mathcal{F}(d)f∗​F(d) is finite rank locally free sheaf for d≫0d\gg 0d≫0.

Proof

Proof. The problem is local on YYY so we may assume Y=SpecAY=\mathrm{Spec}AY=SpecA, where AAA is a noetherian local ring. Then the theorem becomes: F\mathcal{F}F is flat if and only if H0(X,F(d))H^{0}(X,\mathcal{F}(d))H0(X,F(d)) is free AAA-module for d≫0d\gg 0d≫0. This is what we proved in Ha3 III theorem 9.9. ◻

Theorem 6. Let f:X→Sf:X\to Sf:X→S be a projective morphism over noetherian scheme SSS. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX. Now we do the stratification for the general case. Let YYY be an irreducible component of SSS. Now apply the stratification for the special case of the coherent sheaves {Ei:f∗F(N+i)}i=0n\{\mathcal{E}_{i}:f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+i)\}_{i=0}^{n}{Ei​:f∗​F(N+i)}i=0n​ on SSS. Thus for each iii and eee, we have a stratum Wi,eW_{i,e}Wi,e​ by the base change properties 2. and 3., we have e=rankEi∣Wi,e=PFs(N+i)e=\mathrm{rank}\mathcal{E}_{i}|_{W_{i,e}}=P_{\mathcal{F}_{s}}(N+i)e=rankEi​∣Wi,e​​=PFs​​(N+i). For any sequence (e0,…,en)∈Zn+1(e_{0},\dots,e_{n})\in \mathbb{Z}^{n+1}(e0​,…,en​)∈Zn+1 which by the fact above, corresponding to a polynomial PPP, we know as the schematic intersection WP0=⋂i=0nWi,eW_{P}^{0}=\bigcap\limits_{i=0}^{n}W_{i,e}WP0​=i=0⋂n​Wi,e​. By definition, a map φ:T→S\varphi:T\to Sφ:T→S factors through WP0W_{P}^{0}WP0​ if and only if φ∗f∗F(N+i)\varphi^{*}f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+i)φ∗f∗​F(N+i) is locally free of rank ei=P(N+i)e_{i}=P(N+i)ei​=P(N+i) for i=0,…,ni=0,\dots, ni=0,…,n. In particular, s∈WP0s\in W_{P}^{0}s∈WP0​, if and only if PFs(d)=P(d)P_{\mathcal{F}_{s}}(d)=P(d)PFs​​(d)=P(d) and so by the flatness the Hilbert polynomials {WP0}\{W_{P}^{0}\}{WP0​} is a finite locally closed stratification of SSS which has the correct underlying space. We also need to determine the scheme structure. By 2., we know that the formation of f∗F(N+a)f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+a)f∗​F(N+a) is compatible with arbitary base change for all a≥0a\geq 0a≥0. Now for each d≥0d\geq 0d≥0, apply the stratification to the sheaf f∗F(N+n+d)∣WP0f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+n+d)|_{W_{P}^{0}}f∗​F(N+n+d)∣WP0​​ to obtain a locally closed subscheme WPdW_{P}^{d}WPd​. On WPdW_{P}^{d}WPd​, the sheaf f∗F(N+d+n)∣WPdf_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+d+n)|_{W_{P}^{d}}f∗​F(N+d+n)∣WPd​​ is locally free of rank P(N+n+d)P(N+n+d)P(N+n+d). Note at each closed point of WP0W_{P}^{0}WP0​, the rank of f∗F(N+n+d)f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+n+d)f∗​F(N+n+d) is exactly P(N+n+d)P(N+n+d)P(N+n+d), so WPdW_{P}^{d}WPd​ has the same underlying reduced subscheme. In particular, it’s a closed subscheme of WP0W_{P}^{0}WP0​ and it is cut out by some ideal sheaf IPd\mathcal{I}_{P}^{d}IPd​. Consider the chain IP1⊂IP1+IP2⊂⋯I_{P}^{1}\subset \mathcal{I}_{P}^{1}+\mathcal{I}_{P}^{2}\subset \cdotsIP1​⊂IP1​+IP2​⊂⋯. By the noetherian property, the chain is stabled and the final ideal sheaf is I\mathcal{I}I. Let the closed subscheme corresponding to I\mathcal{I}I be SPS_{P}SP​ (or equivalently, SPS_{P}SP​ is the schematic intersection of all WPdW_{P}^{d}WPd​).

SPS_{P}SP​ forms a stratification of SSS. By the definition φ:T→S\varphi:T\to Sφ:T→S factors through SPS_{P}SP​ if and only if for all a≥0a\geq 0a≥0, φ∗f∗F(N+a)\varphi^{*}f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+a)φ∗f∗​F(N+a) is locally free of rank P(N+a)P(N+a)P(N+a), but by the base change, φ∗f∗F(N+a)=(fT)∗FT(N+a)\varphi^{*}f_{*}\mathcal{F}(N+a)=(f_{T})_{*}\mathcal{F}_{T}(N+a)φ∗f∗​F(N+a)=(fT​)∗​FT​(N+a). Thus φ:T→S\varphi:T\to Sφ:T→S factors through SPS_{P}SP​ if and only if (fT)∗FT(N+a)(f_{T})_{*}\mathcal{F}_{T}(N+a)(fT​)∗​FT​(N+a) is locally free of rank P(N+a)P(N+a)P(N+a) for all a≥0a\geq 0a≥0 if and only if FT\mathcal{F}_{T}FT​ is flat over TTT with Hilbert polynomial P(d)P(d)P(d). ◻

Moreover, the pullback sheaf FS′\mathcal{F}_{S'}FS′​ is flat over SSS and any morphism φ:T→S\varphi:T\to Sφ:T→S factor through S′S'S′ if FT\mathcal{F}_{T}FT​ is flat over TTT.

Grothendieck Existence Theorem

Theorem 7. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a projective morphism noetherian schemes. L=OX(1)\mathcal{L}=\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)L=OX​(1) is very ample sheaf over YYY. Φ∈Q[t]\Phi\in \mathbb{Q}[t]Φ∈Q[t] is a polynomial. Let F\mathcal{F}F be a coherent sheaf on XXX which is a quotient of some sheaf E=OX(m)r\mathcal{E}=\mathcal{O}_{X}(m)^{r}E=OX​(m)r for some r∈Nr\in \mathbb{N}r∈N, m∈Zm\in \mathbb{Z}m∈Z. Then the quotient functor QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is represented by a scheme QuotF/X/YΦ,LQuot_{\mathcal{F}/X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ which is projective over YYY.

Note if YYY is affine noetherian scheme, any coherent sheaf is a quotient of some OX(m)r\mathcal{O}_{X}(m)^{r}OX​(m)r. See Ha3 II theorem 5.18.

We will do the proof in a lemma and several steps.

Using the facts that g∗M=fS∗FS(l)g^{*}\mathcal{M}=f_{S*}\mathcal{F}_{S}(l)g∗M=fS∗​FS​(l) and G\mathfrak{G}G is locally free. We know the sequence 0→fG∗L→fG∗π∗M→fG∗G→00\to f_{G}^{*}\mathcal{L}\to f_{G}^{*}\pi^{*}\mathcal{M}\to f_{G}^{*}\mathfrak{G}\to 00→fG∗​L→fG∗​π∗M→fG∗​G→0 pulls back via the induced morphism XS→XGX_{S}\to X_{G}XS​→XG​ to the exact sequence 0→fS∗fS∗K(l)→fS∗fS∗FS(l)→fS∗fS∗G(l)→00\to f_{S}^{*}f_{S*}\mathcal{K}(l)\to f_{S}^{*}f_{S*}\mathcal{F}_{S}(l)\to f_{S}^{*}f_{S*}\mathcal{G}(l)\to 00→fS∗​fS∗​K(l)→fS∗​fS∗​FS​(l)→fS∗​fS∗​G(l)→0. Therefore the morphism ccc pulls back fG∗G→FG→Rf_{G}^{*}\mathcal{G}\to \mathcal{F}_{G}\to \mathcal{R}fG∗​G→FG​→R to fS∗fS∗K(l)→FS(l)→G(l)→0f_{S}^{*}f_{S*}\mathcal{K}(l)\to \mathcal{F}_{S}(l)\to \mathcal{G}(l)\to 0fS∗​fS∗​K(l)→FS​(l)→G(l)→0. In particular, R(−l)\mathcal{R}(-l)R(−l) is the pullback of G\mathcal{G}G which is flat over SSS.

Using the stratification of GGG for the sheaf R(−l)\mathcal{R}(-l)R(−l), we know that the morphism h:S→Gh:S\to Gh:S→G factors through the locally closed subscheme G′G'G′. On the other hand, any morphism S→GS\to GS→G over YYY which factors through G′G'G′ is will give a quotient of FS\mathcal{F}_{S}FS​ in QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S) which is the pullback of the quotient FS→R(−l)\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{R}(-l)FS​→R(−l). Thus the scheme G′G'G′ with the universal family FG→R(−l)\mathcal{F}_{G}\to \mathcal{R}(-l)FG​→R(−l) restricted to XG′X_{G'}XG′​ represents the functor QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​.

Step 7. We need to show G′G'G′ is closed subset of GGG. GGG is projective so we only need to show G′G'G′ is proper. We check this by valuation criterion. For DVR RRR and it’s field of fraction KKK, let T=SpecKT=\mathrm{Spec}KT=SpecK and S=SpecRS=\mathrm{Spec}RS=SpecR. Consider the commutative diagram

which induces the commutative diagram

If we pullback FG→R(−l)\mathcal{F}_{G}\to \mathcal{R}(-l)FG​→R(−l), we will get FT→G\mathcal{F}_{T}\to \mathcal{G}FT​→G in QuotF/X/YΦ,L(T)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(T)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(T), from which we also get a morphism j∗′FT→j∗′Gj'_{*}\mathcal{F}_{T}\to j'_{*}\mathcal{G}j∗′​FT​→j∗′​G. On the other hand, since FT=j′∗FS\mathcal{F}_{T}=j'^{*}\mathcal{F}_{S}FT​=j′∗FS​, there’s a natural morphism FS→j∗′FT\mathcal{F}_{S}\to j'_{*}\mathcal{F}_{T}FS​→j∗′​FT​ and thus a morphism φ:FS→j∗′G\varphi:\mathcal{F}_{S}\to j'_{*}\mathcal{G}φ:FS​→j∗′​G, a quotient FS→H\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{H}FS​→H, where H\mathcal{H}H is the image of φ\varphiφ. Since G\mathcal{G}G is flat over TTT, j∗′j'_{*}j∗′​ is flat over SSS. Moreover, since RRR is DVR, any subsheaf of j∗′Gj'_{*}\mathcal{G}j∗′​G is flat over SpecR\mathrm{Spec}RSpecR hence H\mathcal{H}H is flat over SSS(RRR is PID so flat   ⟺  \iff⟺ torsion free). Thus the Hilbert polynomial of H\mathcal{H}H on the fibres of XS→SX_{S}\to SXS​→S is the same over the points of SSS. Therefore the quotient FS→H\mathcal{F}_{S}\to\mathcal{H}FS​→H is an element in QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X /Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S). By our construction, the pullback of FS→H\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{H}FS​→H to XTX_{T}XT​ coincide with FT→G\mathcal{F}_{T}\to \mathcal{G}FT​→G. Moreover, the arguments in Step 6 show that FG→R(−l)\mathcal{F}_{G}\to \mathcal{R}(-l)FG​→R(−l) pulls back to FS→H\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{H}FS​→H. Therefore there’s a unique morphism S→G′S\to G'S→G′ over YYY which restricts to the given morphism T→G′T\to G'T→G′. Properness is done by valuation criterion. ◻

Lemma 5. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be projective morphism of noetherian schemes, OX(1)\mathcal{O}_{X}(1)OX​(1) a very ample sheaf on YYY, and Φ∈Q[t]\Phi\in \mathbb{Q}[t]Φ∈Q[t] a polynomial. Let F′→F\mathcal{F}'\to \mathcal{F}F′→F be a surjective morphism of coherent sheaves on XXX. If QuotF′/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}' /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF′/X/YΦ,L​ is represented by a scheme QuotF′/X/YΦ,LQuot_{\mathcal{F}' /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF′/X/YΦ,L​, then QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is represented by a closed subscheme of QuotF′/X/YΦ,LQuot_{\mathcal{F}' /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF′/X/YΦ,L​.

Proof

Proof. Let Q′=QuotF′/X/YΦ,LQ'=Quot_{\mathcal{F}' /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}Q′=QuotF′/X/YΦ,L​, and G′\mathfrak{G}'G′ be the universal family on XQ′X_{Q'}XQ′​ which comes with a surjective morphism FQ′′→G′\mathcal{F}'_{Q'}\to \mathfrak{G}'FQ′′​→G′ whose kernel is denoted by L\mathcal{L}L. The given morphism F′→F\mathcal{F}'\to \mathcal{F}F′→F also gives a surjective morphism FQ′′→FQ′\mathcal{F}'_{Q'}\to \mathcal{F}_{Q'}FQ′′​→FQ′​ whose kernel is denoted by N\mathcal{N}N. Put R=FQ′′/(L+N)\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{F}'_{Q'} /(\mathcal{L}+\mathcal{N})R=FQ′′​/(L+N), we have a commutative diagram

Let Q=QΦ′Q=Q'_{\Phi}Q=QΦ′​ be the locally closed subscheme of Q′Q'Q′ corresponding to Φ\PhiΦ given by the stratification of Q′Q'Q′ for the sheaf R\mathcal{R}R. Now let g:S→Yg:S\to Yg:S→Y be the morphism from a noetherian scheme, FS→G\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{G}FS​→G be an element in QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​. The surjection FS′→FS\mathcal{F}'_{S}\to \mathcal{F}_{S}FS′​→FS​ composed with FS→G\mathcal{F}_{S}\to \mathcal{G}FS​→G gives a quotient FS′→G\mathcal{F}_{S}'\to \mathcal{G}FS′​→G in QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S). Thus we have a natural transformation QuotF/X/YΦ,L(S)→QuotF′/X/YΦ,L(S)\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)\to \mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F}' /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}(S)QuotF/X/YΦ,L​(S)→QuotF′/X/YΦ,L​(S). Moreover, the quotient FS′→G\mathcal{F}_{S}'\to \mathcal{G}FS′​→G uniquely determines a morphism h:S→Q′h:S\to Q'h:S→Q′ such that c:XS→XQ′c:X_{S}\to X_{Q'}c:XS​→XQ′​ is the induced morphism then the quotient FQ′→G\mathcal{F}_{Q}'\to \mathfrak{G}FQ′​→G is pulled back to FS′→G\mathcal{F}_{S}'\to \mathcal{G}FS′​→G via ccc. So we have the commutative diagram

By the construction, the morphism α\alphaα factors through the morphism β\betaβ hence the image of c∗Lc^{*}\mathcal{L}c∗L contains the image of c∗Nc^{*}\mathcal{N}c∗N, which implies that the image of c∗Lc^{*}\mathcal{L}c∗L is equal to the image of c∗(L+N)c^{*}(\mathcal{L}+\mathcal{N})c∗(L+N). Thus γ\gammaγ is an isomorphism. This also implies that h:S→Q′h:S\to Q'h:S→Q′ factors through QQQ. Therefore the functor QuotF/X/YΦ,L\mathcal{Q}uot_{\mathcal{F} /X/Y}^{\Phi,\mathcal{L}}QuotF/X/YΦ,L​ is represented by the scheme QQQ and the quotient FQ→R\mathcal{F}_{Q}\to \mathcal{R}FQ​→R restricted to XQX_{Q}XQ​. QQQ is a closed subscheme of Q′Q'Q′ by valuation criterion for properness similar to the proof of the main theorem. ◻
